Raleigh, NC 27347
1-800-662-7924 ext. 212

node.Title: John R. Kernodle, Jr. Memorial Scholarship Fund
node.Body:
Established by a Guilford County citizens committee in memory of John R. Kernodle, Jr., this scholarship assists future educators with their undergraduate studies. Scholarships are awarded based on financial need and merit to graduating seniors of the Guilford County public high schools who are legal residents of North Carolina. Special consideration if given to students attending North Carolina colleges and universities. Scholars are required to serve for a minimum of three years following graduation in a field directly benefiting public education in North Carolina. The Kernodle Scholarship pays a maximum of $10,000 per year for four year.
 
Who is eligible?
High School seniors in Guilford County

Eligibility Requirements

  • Demonstrated financial need
  • Depth of character
  • Well-rounded interests
  • Potential for success at the college level
  • Commitment to community service
  • Leadership ability
  • Extracurricular involvement
  • Maintain a minimum cumulative 3.0 grade point average while in college

 Contact Information
Jean Goodman
The Community Foundation of Greater Greensboro
100 South Elm St., Suite 307
Greensboro, NC 27401-2638
910-379-9100
Applications must be hand-delivered or post-marked no later then the specified date in April. Recipients will be notified in May.

node.Title: The John Paul Lucas, Jr. Scholarship for Educational Leadership
node.Body:
This scholarship was established in memory of John Paul Lucas, Jr., to recognize and support students who are pursuing a graduate degree in English and intends to teach in North or South Carolina.

This scholarship was made possible by the generous contribution of Mr. and Mrs. John Paul Lucas, Jr..

Typical Award Amount*: $1000

*Award amount represents an average of the last three years' awards and future awards are subject to the availability of funds.

Application Deadline Date: March 1 

Scholarship Criteria

  • Student pursuing a masters degree in English, English Education, Middle Grades Education (6-9), Secondary Education (9-12), or Middle Grades & Secondary Education
  • Concentration in English, English Language Arts, English Secondary Education, Middle Grades English and Communication, Creative Writing, English for Specific Purposes, Children's Literature, Linguistics, Literature, Rhetoric and Composition, Teaching English as a Second Language, or Technical and Professional Writing
  • New or continuing masters student admitted to a graduate program (regardless of admit term)
  • Full Time
  • U.S. citizen
  • Student should intend to teach in North or South Carolina

To Apply for This Scholarship or For More Information

To apply for this and all UNC Charlotte scholarships go to our NinerScholars Portal. For more detailed information about this scholarship, please contact Julie Green at 704-687-7268 or contact the University Scholarship Office by emailing Scholarships@uncc.edu or calling 704-687-5871.

node.Title: The Dottie Martin Teachers Scholarship
node.Body:
The North Carolina Federation of Republican Women established the Dottie Martin Teachers Scholarship Fund in 1991 in honor of First Lady Dottie Martin's work and dedication to the families and youth of North Carolina. This annual scholarship of $500 is designed for a man or woman presently enrolled and studying in the field of education. An objective is to assist aspiring teachers who are particularly interested in child guidance and counseling and who want to make a difference in the lives of North Carolina's children.
 
Who is eligible? 
Undergraduate students
 
Eligibility Requirements

  • Financial need
  • Must be well-advanced in programs of Education with an established  career plan for teaching.

 
Contact Information

Applications can be obtained online

Applications are due in late May and awards are announced in early August

node.Title: CVAN Battered Women's Program: John and Mary O'Dwyer Flynn Memorial Scholarship
node.Body:
The CVAN - John and Mary O'Dwyer Flynn Scholarship was established in 1988 to provide financial assistance for women. The Scholarship was established by the friends and family of Mary O'Dwyer Flynn, a social worker and Professor at The National Catholic School of Social Service at Catholic University in Washington, D.C., and John J. Flynn, Jr., an attorney in Washington, D.C. Scholarship amounts range from $200 - $500. Scholarships may be used for tuition, books, fees, supplies, transportation, and/or child care. Applications are considered on an ongoing basis.
 
Who is eligible?

  • Female students attending a post secondary school
  • Demonstrated potential for academic success
  • Preference given to formally battered women and children of battered women.
  • Preference will be given to Cabarrus County residents

Contact Information
CVAN Scholarship Committee
P.O. Box 1749
Concord, NC 28026-1749
704.788.1108

node.Title: Bright Futures Award: National Early Childhood Education Scholarship Program
node.Body:
Purpose: Bright Horizons believes the profession of early childhood education deserves more respect and support. It is our hope that this scholarship will be a way to encourage students of great promise to continue pursuing their dreams of teaching young children.

Award Amount: 

Three scholarships are available for students pursuing degrees in early childhood education who meet the criteria below up to these amount levels:

  1.  $1500 Scholarship for those entering their second year of an Associate’s degree program.
  2.  $2500 Scholarship for those entering their junior year in a Bachelor’s degree program.
  3.  $2500 Scholarship for those enrolled in a Master’s degree program.

Application: more information and application available at www.brighthorizons.com/scholarship

node.Body:

Applications can be downloaded from November through February. Completed applications are due March 1. The award is announced in June and is applied to the next school year.

node.Title: Middle Grades University Endowed Scholarship
node.Body:
Middle Grades University Endowed Scholarship is designed to enhance the lives of “at educational-risk youth” (defined as youth in groups underrepresented in post-secondary Education institutions, such as low-income groups) through a scholarship fund at UNC Charlotte.

Criteria for the scholarship are as follows:

  • At educational risk youth (with demonstrated financial need)
  • Grade average of B or better
  • Employed part time or experience performing community service
  • Successful participation in the Middle Grades University Program
  • Acceptance into a degree program at UNC Charlotte, with special consideration given to those enrolled in the College of Education.
  • Three letters of recommendation from Teen Health Connection, teachers, community service organizations, employers, or clergy

For more information and to apply visit the main UNC Charlotte Scholarship page.

node.Title: Jacqueline F. and Robert F. Hull, Jr. Scholarship for Lateral Entry Teachers
node.Body:
Purpose:  
Provide scholarship to a lateral entry teacher seeking licensure

Award Amount: Varies

Who should apply:
1.      A student admitted to the College of Education's Graduate Certificate in Teaching program
2.      A current Lateral Entry teacher

Scholarship Criteria:

1.      North Carolina resident
2.      Financial need
3.      Must show commitment to the teaching program

For more information and to apply visit the main UNC Charlotte Scholarship page.

node.Title: The Michael G. Green Family Scholarship for Merit**
node.Body:
Purpose:  This merit scholarship will be awarded annually to a high-performing Elementary Education major.

Award Amount:  varies

Who is eligible:

  • Undergraduate students who have been admitted to the Elementary Education program

Scholarship Criteria:

  1.  Recipient shall be admitted to the College of Education
  2. Student’s designated major must be Elementary Education (ELED) with a concentration or minor in Mathematics
  3. Recipient shall have demonstrated academic achievement by maintaining an overall GPA of 3.75 or higher
  4. Recipient shall have demonstrated financial need in the broadest sense as determined by the Office of Financial Aid

**Does not require application.

For more information and to apply visit the main UNC Charlotte Scholarship page.

node.Title: Adapted Curriculum Licensure Plus Project Grant
node.Body:
Purpose: The purpose of this project is to increase the number of highly qualified teachers of students with severe disabilities, to improve training preparation and build knowledge of academic content, to enhance the skills of current teachers to fill identified needs in services, and to meet the needs of students with autism and English-language learners. The desired outcome of this project is to have more and better trained teachers licensed to serve students with severe disabilities in classrooms in North Carolina and states who have reciprocal licensure agreements with North Carolina. The grant is funded until 2016. We offer courses which lead to the Adapted Curriculum Graduate Certificate, a M. Ed. in Special Education, or MAT degree in Special Education-Adapted Curriculum. We also provide the added value of courses designed to help those who teach students with Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD), or Spanish  courses for those who teach or plan to teach ESL students with severe disabilities, as well as courses in additional academic content. If you are interested in funding, please be aware that you must agree to serve students with severe disabilities upon completion of the program as required by our grantors in the US Department of Education.

Amount: Varies

Who should apply:

  1. Those students who are interested/enrolled in:
  • Graduate Certificate in Adapted Curriculum Special Education
  • M.Ed. in Special Education
  • MAT in Special education-Adapted Curriculum
    (Any student specifically interested in additional coursework in Autism Spectrum Disorders or ESL for those with severe disabilities.)

Scholarship criteria:

  1. Be enrolled in one of the above programs
  2. Agreement to serve students with severe disabilities post-graduation

More information on the Department of Special Education website

node.Title: The Alma and Sharon Goudes Educational Scholarship
node.Body:
Purpose: Established by Nicholas Goudes in memory of his wife, Alma, and his daughter, Sharon, for scholarships for students who have demonstrated their intention to teach English or Math at the middle or high school level.

Award Amount: Varies

Who should apply?

  • Undergraduate and Graduate Certifiicate students admitted to teacher education in any one of the following programs:
  • English major with minor in Secondary Education
  • Mathematics major with minor in Secondary Education
  • Middle Grades major with concentration in English Language Arts
  • Middle Grades major with concentration in Mathematics
  • Previous recipients of the scholarship who are applying to renew it for one or two semesters of their senior year.

Scholarship Criteria:

  1. Must taking courses in the Department of Middle, Secondary, and K-12 Education in the College of Education, with the commitment to complete student teaching and obtain a teaching license at the time of graduation.
  2. Preference given to applicants who indicate their intention to teach in North Carolina, particularly those who intend to teach at a secondary school in Mecklenburg County, North Carolina.
  3. May be financial and/or merit based.

For more information and to apply visit the main UNC Charlotte Scholarship page.

node.Title: Dr. Herman Thomas Scholarship for Teachers
node.Body:
Purpose: Fund to provide financial assistance to student(s) in the College of Education’s teacher education program.

Award Amount:  varies

Who should apply:

  • A rising junior who has been admitted to a teacher education program in the College of Education
  • Who has completed the University Transition Opportunities Program (UTOP)

Scholarship Criteria:

  1. Minimum 3.0 GPA
  2. Must be an active leader on campus and in the community
  3. Must have financial need as determined by the Office of Financial Aid
  4. Must meet criteria to be renewable in senior year.
  5. Preference for minority students

NOTE:  Scholarship must be awarded in junior year and cannot be awarded to a senior without having been awarded in their junior year.  If there are no eligible candidates, funds are to remain until a rising junior meets the criteria.

For more information and to apply visit the main UNC Charlotte Scholarship page.

node.Title: Military Order of the Purple Heart Scholarship
node.Body:
Purpose: Established in 1988 by the American Association of Colleges for Teacher Education for Education majors who have shown scholarly achievement, teaching ability, and concern for the educational rights of children with disabilities.

Award Amount: varies

Who should apply:

  • A junior admitted to a teacher education program

Scholarship criteria:

  1. Scholarly achievement
  2. Teaching ability
  3. Concern for the educational rights of children with disabilities.

For more information and to apply visit the main UNC Charlotte Scholarship page.

node.Title: Ronald Anderson Memorial Scholarship
node.Body:
Purpose:  Established in memory of Dr. Ronald Anderson, a professor in the former Dept of Counseling, Special Education and Child Development, by his colleagues and friends for students who desire a career in teaching

Award Amount: varies

Who should apply:

A rising senior who has been admitted to a teacher education program

Scholarship criteria:

  1. Rising senior seeking a career in teaching 
  2. It is preferred that recipients are persons who have experienced significant physical difficulties; however, this is not a requirement for selection

For more information and to apply visit the main UNC Charlotte Scholarship page.

node.Title: The Bertha and Irving Fishman Scholarship
node.Body:
Purpose:  This scholarship fund has been established by Dr. Stephen M. Fishman in memory of his parents, Bertha and Irving Fishman, and especially to honor his mother, who taught students at the middle school level.

Award Amount: varies

Who should apply:

  • A rising junior admitted to the major in Middle Grades Education OR
  • A rising senior who received the award in the previous year

Scholarship Criteria:

  1. Overall GPA of 3.0 or higher
  2. Demonstrated financial need
  3. Demonstrated commitment to teaching middle grades students (e.g., evidence of prior work with  children of this age)

Note: May be awarded for two years to same individual who continues to meet scholarship criteria

For more information and to apply visit the main UNC Charlotte Scholarship page.

node.Title: Jane N. and Seddon Goode, Jr. Scholars Endowment Fund for the College of Education
node.Body:
Purpose: Fund used to provide scholarship assistance to students studying to become teachers

Award Amount: varies

Who should apply:

  • Students accepted at UNC Charlotte who are committed to becoming teachers

Scholarship Criteria:

  1. Recipient shall have demonstrated academic achievement by maintaining a 3.0 GPA
  2. Recipients shall be recruited by or admitted to a teacher education program in the College of Education
  3. Recipients shall have demonstrated financial need in the broadest sense

For more information and to apply visit the main UNC Charlotte Scholarship page.

node.Title: Bob and Mary Faye Combs Scholarship
node.Body:
Purpose: This scholarship was created in memory of Mary Faye Combs by her husband B. E. Combs as a tribute to her dedication to teaching.

Award Amount: Varies

Who should apply:

  • Junior/senior admitted to a teacher education program in the College of Education

Scholarship Criteria:

1. An overall GPA of 2.5 or higher

2. Based upon merit and financial need

3. Preference given to residents of Iredell County and/or North Carolina

Note:  Renewable upon continuing to meet qualifications

For more information and to apply visit the main UNC Charlotte Scholarship page.

node.Title: Eve H. Buchanan-cates and J. Mark Cates Endowed Scholarship for Teachers
node.Body:
Purpose: Established to recruit and retain aspiring upper-class teachers who have participated in the Freshman Sophomore Learning Community

Award Amount: varies

Who should apply:

Rising Junior admitted to a teacher education program

Scholarship Criteria:

  1. Must have participated in the Freshman/Sophomore Learning Community for Teachers for three semesters
  2. Must be accepted in the College of Education
  3. Must have a 3.0 GPA or higher

For more information and to apply visit the main UNC Charlotte Scholarship page.

node.Title: The Cato Scholars
node.Body:
Purpose: Fund established by the Cato Corporation to provide scholarships to students studying to become elementary and middle school teachers who best meet scholarship criteria

Award Amount: varies

Who should apply:

  • Students admitted to UNC Charlotte who are committed to becoming elementary or middle school teachers.

Scholarship Criteria:

  1. Recipient shall be recruited by or admitted to the College of Education
  2. Student’s designated major must be Pre-Elementary Education (PELM), Pre-Middle Grades     
  3. (PMDL), Elementary Education (ELED), or Middle Grades (MDLG)
  4. Recipient shall have demonstrated academic achievement by maintaining an overall GPA of     
  5. 3.0 or higher
  6. Recipient shall have demonstrated financial need in the broadest sense as determined by the
  7.  Office of Financial Aid

NOTE: Up to four Cato Scholars may be chosen each year.  The award is renewable for up to four years as long as the recipient continues  to meet criteria

For more information and to apply visit the main UNC Charlotte Scholarship page.

node.Title: Mary Cizauskas-Antonelli Memorial Scholarship
node.Body:
Purpose:  Scholarship for outstanding senior teacher education student

Who should apply:

  • Teacher education student who is enrolled in his/her fourth year at UNC Charlotte

Scholarship Criteria:

  1.  Student preparing to teach who has the highest GPA in 4 years at UNC Charlotte
  2.  Admitted to a teacher education program

For more information and to apply visit the main UNC Charlotte Scholarship page.

node.Title: Antonelli Memorial Fund Scholarship
node.Body:
Purpose:  Provide scholarship to outstanding teacher education student

Award Amount: Varies

Who should apply:

  1. A rising senior admitted to and enrolled in a teacher education program

Scholarship Criteria:

  1. Highest GPA in three years at UNC Charlotte

node.Title: North Carolina Alpha Chapter of Alpha Delta Kappa Memorial Scholarship
node.Body:
Purpose: Established in 1967 by the NC Alpha Chapter of Alpha Delta Kappa Honorary Sorority for Women Educators. The fund is reserved for talented and deserving students in the College of Education.

Award Amount:  varies 

Who should apply?

  • A junior or senior admitted to a teacher education program

Scholarship criteria:

  1. Minimum overall GPA of 3.8 or higher
  2. Unmet financial need
  3. Cannot be student teaching during  Fall semester, and therefore, be scheduled to graduated in December

 Other Considerations:

 Scholarship may be awarded to the same individual (when awarded to a junior) for a maximum of two years.

Former donor request to have recipient attend membership meetings is nullified based upon disbanding of membership 2006.

For more information and to apply visit the main UNC Charlotte Scholarship page.

node.Title: Giving to the College of Education
node.Body:
Ways to give:
Annual Giving
Major Gifts
Planned Giving
Ways to Make a Gift

Annual Giving

Each year, UNC Charlotte contacts College of Education alumni and friends through a telefundraising campaign to invite annual gifts in support of the University. Gifts to the annual giving program provide vital operating support for priority initiatives in the College of Education. You can designate your gift to the college, program or department that is meaningful to you or you can apply your gift to the Chancellor's Fund, which offers flexibility and valuable financial support university-wide.

By investing in the College of Education through the annual giving program, you demonstrate how much you value, believe in and support our college and its mission. Your annual gifts support such things as:

  • Student Scholarships
  • Graduate Assistantships
  • Faculty Recruitment and Retention
  • Travel Grants
  • Guest Lecturers
  • Student and Faculty Program Support

What are Major Gifts?

Major gifts serve two primary purposes in the College of Education at UNC Charlotte: they create long-term financial stability for the college, and they provide opportunities to merge donors' interests with the college’s various needs and objectives. Major gifts earmarked forendowment help build, restore and sustain our academic programs.

Major Gifts at Work

The College of Education appreciates the support of all our generous donors. Donors who support the college through major gifts can designate their support toward a specific purpose such as a scholarship or program that matches their personal interests with the college’s priorities. Major gifts may also lead to recognition opportunities, which can either honor the donor directly or honor or memorialize a special person of the donor's choosing.

What are some examples?

Major gifts can be established to support scholarships, faculty development and various academic programs.Major gifts may also be used to support certain programsand/or departments in the college. Gifts fall into the following categories:

Endowment Gifts:
Endowment gifts are invested and managed by the university, and the income from the gift is directed toward a purpose selected by the donor. The university only expends income generated from the gift's principal, in accordance with the university's spending regulations. Income earned in excess of the amount spent annually is reinvested into the endowment so that it grows in perpetuity, providing “purchasing power” for future generations, despite economic conditions.  For further description see the giving website.

Restricted Current Use Gifts:
There are many options in which donors may direct their support to college initiatives that hold personal significance. Gifts may be designated for any purpose that contributes to the college’s mission of teaching, research and service. Unlike endowed funds, restricted current use funds are depleted over a specified period of time. For example, a donor may wish to support students by creating an award that is funded and expended annually. 

Unrestricted Gifts:
Some of the most useful and flexible gifts to the college are those that are unrestricted. Unrestricted gifts are used to support the day-to-day operations of the college, including student activities, general financial aid, teaching, and research.

Planned Giving

Many UNC Charlotte alumni, friends and donors choose to support the university's work through planned gifts, which include gifts of marketable securities such as stocks and bonds; estate gifts through a bequest in a will or through a trust; charitable gift annuities or charitable remainder trusts that provide a lifetime income stream to the donor; and other gifts of real estate or tax-deferred retirement assets.

Planned gifts provide financial flexibility and various tax benefits. Planned gifts also provide an effective means of financial stewardship, redirecting money to needs that would otherwise become lost to estate, capital gains or income taxes. Because a planned gift requires careful consideration of a donor's personal, financial and charitable goals and desires, we encourage you to consult with your financial, tax or legal adviser.

By making your planned gift at UNC Charlotte, you'll become a member of the prestigious Bonnie Cone Society, which recognizes those individuals who have included the university in their long-term financial and estate planning. The following are various planned giving options listed below

  • Bequests from Wills
  • Charitable Gift Annuities
  • Life Insurance & Annuity Contracts
  • Charitable Remainder Trusts
  • Qualified Retirement Plans
  • Retained Life Estates

Ways to Make a Gift

There are numerous ways you can make your gift to the College of Education. We invite you to make your annual gift in support of the college’s ongoing needs, or perhaps consider making a major or planned gift for an endowment.  We will work with you to structure a gift that is most meaningful to you.

Options to make your gift:

  • Online Gifts
  • Matching gifts from employers increases support to the college
  • Check
  • Credit Card
  • Payroll Deduction
  • Bank Draft

Additional Options: appreciated securities (stocks and bonds) or property, such as real estate and equipment. In addition, you may choose to name the university as a beneficiary in your will.

You can make your gift or pledge to the College of Education through our safe, secure online giving form and by clicking on this link.

Gifts are tax deductible as permitted by law.

To request information about giving, contact Kathie Goldman, Executive Assistant to the Dean. Kathie.Goldman@uncc.edu or 704-687-8994

node.Title: Graduate Certificate Programs
node.Body:
The UNC Charlotte Cato College of Education offers a variety of graduate certificates. A Bachelor’s degree is required for admission, and specific programs will have additional requirements. 

  •  Initial licensure graduate certificates lead to an initial teaching license and, with further coursework, a Master’s degree. These programs are for individuals who have a bachelor’s degree or career in another area, and are interested in a career in an education field.

  • Non-licensure graduate certificates are for individuals who are interested in learning about a specific topic or expanding their knowledge base that will assist them in furthering their career (i.e.; counseling)
     
  • ​Add-on licensure graduate certificates are for individuals who have a teaching license and a Bachelor’s degree and would like to add an area to their current teaching license.
     
  • ​Advanced licensure graduate certificates are for individuals who already have a teaching or school counseling license and a Master’s degree and are interested in adding another area to their current teaching license.

Graduate Certificates in Teaching (Initial Licensure)

  • Art Education (K-12)​​​
     
  • Child and Family Development (B-K)
  • Elementary Education (K-6)
     
  • Middle Grades Education (6-9)
    • English/language arts, math, science, social studies
       
  • Secondary Education (9-12)
    • Comprehensive science, comprehensive social studies, English, math
       
  • Special Education (K-12)
    • Adapted curriculum, general curriculum

  • Teaching English as a Second Language (K-12)
     
  • Foreign Language Education (K-12)
    • French, German, Spanish

​Graduate Certificates in Teaching (Add-On Licensure)

  • Elementary School Mathematics (K-6)

  • Academically or Intellectually Gifted (K-12)

  • Instructional Systems Technology (K-12)*

*Individuals do not have to have a teaching license in order to pursue this graduate certificate, but if they do, they can receive the 079 special endorsement.

Graduate Certificates in Non-Teaching Areas

  • Autism Spectrum Disorder (non-licensure)

  • Play Therapy (non-licensure)*

  • Substance Abuse Counseling (non-licensure)*

  • School Counseling (Advanced licensure)*

  • Early Childhood Mental Health (B-K)

  • Quantitative Analyses (non-licensure)

  • University and College Teaching

*Must have Master’s degree in counseling, social work, or psychology

Graduate Certificates in School Administration

  • Educational Administration (add-on Advanced licensure)

node.Title: Licensure Programs for Master's Licensure
node.Body:
Master’s Degrees 

Students earning a Master of Arts in Teaching (M.A.T.) degree complete a Graduate Certificate in Teaching (initial licensure) at UNC Charlotte, then take the additional courses that lead to a master’s degree and an advanced teaching license.

Masters of Education (M.Ed.) programs are for current teachers who hold a Bachelor’s degree and a teaching license and are interested in career advancement and becoming a teacher leader in their field. These programs lead to an advanced teaching license.

The Master of School Administration (M.S.A.) prepares innovative, collaborative, effective, and reflective leaders who are prepared to develop school environments that ensure equitable and quality learning opportunities for a rapidly changing and increasingly diverse population and focus on improving the learning for all students

Master of Education (M.Ed.) (for advanced licensure)

  • Child  & Family Studies (B-K)
  • Curriculum & Supervision (K-12) - Note: The College is not currently accepting applicants for this program.
  • Elementary Education(K-6)
  • Instructional Systems Technology(K-12)
  • Middle/Secondary education
    • Middle Grades Track: English/language arts, mathematics, science, or social studies(6-9)
    • Secondary Education Track: comprehensive social studies or comprehensive science(9-12)
  • Reading Education (K-12)
  • Special Education (K-12)

  • Adapted Curriculum
  • General Curriculum

Master of Arts in Teaching (M.A.T.)

A two-phase program providing both Initial and Advanced licensure

  • Elementary education (K-6)
  • Foreign language education: French, German, or Spanish (K-12)
  • Middle grades education: English/ language arts, mathematics, science, or social studies(6-9)
  • Secondary education: English, mathematics, comprehensive social studies, and comprehensive science (9-12)

node.Title: Profile
node.Body:
Vision: Our vision is to be a national leader in educational equity through excellence and engagement.
Students: More than 2,000 students enrolled in programs in the College of Education
Faculty:  115 full-time faculty provide instruction, conduct research, and contribute to both the university and the community through service.
U. S. News and World Report ranks the Cato College of Education #76 out of 629 institutions in the nation.
Recent Alumni Awards:

2017 National Association for Gifted Children Administrator of the Year 

2017 Charlotte-Mecklenburg Schools Exceptional Children's Teacher of the Year

2017 Cabarrus County Schools Principal of the Year

2017 Cabarrus County Schools Assistant Principal of the Year

2017 Rowan-Salisbury Schools Teacher of the Year

2017 Rowan Salisbury Schools Principal of the Year

2017 North Carolina Virtual Public School Teacher of the Year

2016 Kannapolis City Schools Teacher of the Year

2016 Charlotte-Mecklenburg Schools Teacher of the Year

2015 Charlotte-Mecklenburg Schools Teacher of the Year

2016 Gaston County Schools Teacher of the Year

2016 Greene County Schools Teacher of the Year

2016 Ashe County Schools Teacher of the Year

2016 Cabarrus County Schools Teacher of the Year

2016 Cabarrus County Schools Principal of the Year

2016 Cabarrus County Schools Assistant Principal of the Year

2015 Kannapolis City Schools Teacher of the Year

2016 Newton-Conover Schools Assistant Principal of the Year

2015 Stanly County Fine Arts Educator of the Year

  • Dr. Chance Lewis selected as 2016 recipient of the Harshini V. de Silva Award. The award is presented annually to the faculty member who best exemplifies the commitment de Silva, a former UNC Charlotte professor, displayed to graduate student mentorship.
  • Dr. Sejal Foxx named  2015 North Carolina School Counselor Association Counselor Educator of the Year
  • Dr. Rebecca Shore named 2015 North Carolina Arts Education Association Arts Educator of the Year
  • Dr. Scott Kissau named 2015 Teacher of the Year in higher education by the Foreign Language Association of North Carolina
  • Dr. Tracy Rock, associate professor of elementary education, received the 2015 UNC Board of Governors Award for Excellence in Teaching, the most prestigious university system-wide award for superior teaching.  In 2014 Tracy was the recipient of the Bank of America Award for Teaching Excellence, UNC Charlotte’s highest honor for excellence in teaching. 
  • Dr. Drew Polly was awarded with the 2014 Innovator Award by the North Carolina Council of Teachers of Mathematics for his outstanding contributions to mathematics education and schools in North Carolina.
  • Dr. Chance W. Lewis, Carol Grotnes Belk Distinguished Professor of Urban Education was selected as the 2013 recipient of the Dr. Carlos J. Vallejo Memorial Award for Lifetime Scholarship.
  • Dr. Diane M. Browder, received the 2011 O. Max Gardner Award, the highest faculty award presented by the University Of North Carolina Board Of Governors.  She was also awarded the 2009 First Citizens Scholars Medal Award.

 

  • For 2017, the Cato College of Education received over $7.6 million in external funding. From 2013-2017, approximately $36.9 million has been secured from external donors. 
  • Over 120 Charlotte Teach for America (TFA) lateral entry teachers have earned licensure through coursework by completing a Graduate Certificate in Teaching or Master of Arts in Teaching (MAT) through the College of Education.  Currently there are 38 Charlotte-TFA teachers enrolled in the Graduate Certificate in Teaching or MAT programs at UNC Charlotte..

  • Center for Adolescent Literacies
  • Center for Educational Measurement and Evaluation (CEME)
  • Center for Science, Technology, Engineering & Mathematics Education (CSTEM)
  • Multicultural Play Therapy Center
  • National Secondary Transition Technical Assistance Center (OSEP, US-DOE)

Academic Programs in the College of Education

  • 5 Undergraduate Majors (Initial Licensure):  Elementary Education, Special Education-Elementary Education (dual license), Special Education, Middle Grades Education, Child and Family Development.
  • 6 Undergraduate Minors (4 lead to initial licensure):  Foreign Language Education (Licensure), Secondary Education (Licensure), Teaching English as a Second Language (Licensure), Urban Youth and Communities, Reading (Licensure), Child and Family Development.
  • 12 Graduate Certificate Initial Licensure Programs:  Art Education, Dance Education, Foreign Language Education, Middle Grades Education1, Music Education, Secondary Education1, Teaching English as a Second Language, Theatre Education, Elementary Education, Child and Family Development, Special Education: Adapted or General Curriculum1.
  • 3 Add-on Graduate Certificate Licensure Programs:  Elementary Mathematics (K-5) 2, Instructional Systems Technology2, Special Education- Academically & Intellectually Gifted2.
  • 3 Non-Licensure Graduate Certificate Programs:  Autism Spectrum Disorder2, Play Therapy, Substance Abuse Certificate.

  • 3 Master of Arts Programs:  English Education, Math Education, Counseling: Addiction, Clinical Mental Health, School Counseling.
  • 9 Master of Education Programs:  Curriculum & Supervision, Instructional Systems Technology2, Middle Grades and Secondary Education1, Teaching English as a Second Language, Elementary Education1, Reading, Language, and Literacy3, Child & Family Development, Special Education1, Special Education: Academically & Intellectually Gifted2.
  • 1 Master of School Administration Program:  School Administration3.
  • 3 Post Masters Graduate Certificate Programs:  Counseling-School1, Curriculum and Supervision, School Administration.
  • 4 Doctoral Programs:  Counseling, Curriculum and Instruction, Educational Leadership, Special Education.

node.Title: About the College
node.Body:
Welcome to the Cato College of Education at UNC Charlotte!

Our vision is to be a national leader in educational equity, excellence, and engagement. We are committed to preparing teachers, counselors, and school leaders who will provide all youth with access to the highest quality education possible and to meet the needs of all students, regardless of their backgrounds. Our graduates have shown the ability to be successful in all varieties of school and community environments, even the most challenging.  Indeed, many seek out high need contexts where they can make the biggest difference. 

We prepare highly effective and ethical professionals who have a positive impact on children, youth, families, communities, and schools and who are successful in urban and other diverse settings. We enroll approximately 2,400 undergraduate and graduate students annually. Our programs are nationally accredited and approved by the North Carolina Department of Public Instruction. 

We have many award-winning faculty who see teaching as the most important work they do. Several have been nominated for the University’s most prestigious teaching honor, the Bank of America Award for Teaching Excellence. This year, Dr. John Beattie in the Department of Special Education and Child Development is a nominee. In 2014, Dr. Tracy Rock of the Department of Reading and Elementary Education won the award and the $12,500 prize that accompanies it.  If you want to prepare for the challenging, meaningful, and rewarding careers of teaching, counseling, and educational leadership, we invite you to explore the exciting undergraduate and graduate programs and the fabulous faculty members who teach in them on this website.

The Cato College of Education does much more than provide academic programs.  Our faculty members are also involved in cutting edge research related to autism, students with disabilities, struggling readers, why students succeed and fail in college, the teacher shortage, culturally relevant instruction, helping youth with severe disabilities transition into the work place and much more. These studies helped us earn more than $8 million in external funding last year and appear in some of the leading research journals in the field, including Research in Higher Education, Journal of Educational Psychology, and Teachers College Press.

Our faculty and staff also directly and consistently serve the community.  Many work in schools and community agencies serving youth and families with academic and counseling services. Others work through professional organizations leading committee work and serving as editors or reviewers for journals. Many faculty members in the College of Education serve on national-level committees to develop standards for our profession and practice, and several have work that is making a global impact.

As you explore the website, I hope you will find not only the programs you are looking for but the people you want to get to know, learn from and work with.  You will be delighted by the talent and professionalism of the people who work in this College.  If you have questions or comments, please feel free to contact me.

Ellen McIntyre

Dean
